captions.text: *INTRO MUSIC*

Oh boy, another game from Supermassive
&quot;The eternal counterpoint to the aphorism

&#39;practice makes perfect&#39;&quot; Games. Between
Until Dawn and the Dark Pictures

Anthology, Supermassive have made
great strides in the medium of choose

your own adventure books, through the
bold innovative technique of including the

motion captured faces of the least
expensive celebrities to ever set up a

Cameo account. Their new game, The
Quarry, is their most ambitious choose

your own adventure book yet, there&#39;s a
whole three recognisable celebrities in it.

Admittedly with a combined screen time
of about half an hour, but I suppose after

the developers cornered them at a
convention they only had a limited amount

of time before the bodyguards broke
down the toilet door. I remember vaguely

enjoying Until Dawn, I mean, for all that
branching path storytelling is supposed to

offer it had all the replay value of a
traumatic leg amputation, but the over the

top horror and the terribleness of the
characters lent it a certain slasher B-

movie charm. I found the Dark Pricktease
Endoscopy to be one complete waste of

time after another, so now perhaps
understandably Supermassive have gone

back to what worked and made Until
Dawn 2: This Time It&#39;s In A Haunted

Quarry. &#39;Cos it&#39;s pretty much the same
fucking plot: bunch of teenagers played

by out of work 27 year olds come to party
in an isolated house, there&#39;s an

excruciatingly long setup period, and then
monsters in the woods start picking them

off. Only difference is it&#39;s set at a summer
camp, and that just means it took a break

from copy pasting Until Dawn to copy
paste Friday the 13th instead. I&#39;ll say this

for Supermassive Games, they are world
class experts at creating entire casts of

characters that I instantly and completely
despise. They should take a side gig

making war propaganda. If they made one
of these games starring a bunch of

Russian military officers, I&#39;d join the
Ukrainian defense force before you can

say Pierre Kirillovich Bezukhov. A lot of
that comes from the animation. There&#39;s

still an awkwardness about the motion
capture faces, because of course

&quot;Haunted Quarry&quot; is a synonym for
&quot;Uncanny Valley.&quot; There&#39;s something very

wrong with everyone&#39;s mouths and teeth,
like they&#39;ve been enlarged in post-

production or something. The stock &quot;sexy
girl&quot; character in particular looks like she&#39;s

trying to talk through a bagel that&#39;s been
hot glued to her face. But the dialogue

makes me hate them all, too. Everyone&#39;s
got a bad case of verbally explaining their

personalities to each other. &quot;Why are you
always so upbeat?&quot; &quot;Why are you always

cracking jokes?&quot; Those were jokes, were
they. Fuckin&#39; news to me. I couldn&#39;t

decipher them through your private
language of arrogant snorts, and constant

needlessly abrasive digs at each other.
Basically every two way dialog choice

comes down to &quot;be a complete prick&quot; or
&quot;be a partial prick&quot; and even exclusively

taking the second option it still felt
like everyone was trying to break the

loathsomeness speed record. &quot;Okay, I
hated you after six words of dialogue, let&#39;s

see who can beat that. Whoa, hold the
phone, the buff jock dude&#39;s wearing a

backwards baseball cap. He wins. He did
it in zero.&quot; So I hated them for how they

looked and what they said, then they hit
the triple by making me hate them for

what they did, as well. The plot starts
with jock dude deliberately sabotaging

everyone&#39;s ride home so he can have
another stab at getting his leg over sexy

girl. And then of course everyone decides
to have a noisy party because they&#39;re

teenagers in a slasher movie and only
possess three impulses: throw a noisy

party, strip down to their underpants, or
stand around gormlessly in front of a thing

to which they can be easily nailed. But let&#39;s
leave my other story complaints for after

the spoiler warning. There have been
some gameplay refinements. The game no

longer tracks each character&#39;s stats, I guess
they realised that no one bought for

a second that that was any less pointless
than tracking their number of nostrils. And

now there&#39;s a lives system, if someone dies
and you have some bizarre personality

deviance that meant you didn&#39;t want them
to die, you can spend a life to take back a

choice or two and try to save them. Which
I guess is a positive addition because

once again you have absolutely bugger all
hope of intuiting what outcome any of

your decisions will have. You&#39;ll decide not
to pick up a box of fireworks in chapter

two because you have no way of knowing
you need them to fight the Venusian

cockspigot at one specific point in
chapter nine. Besides that, yeah, it&#39;s Until

Dawn again, choose your own adventure
format, quick time events, horrible sticky

third person movement, smug weirdo
narrator interrupting the action every now

and again to remind you to put careful
thought into your next completely random

decision. And like all Supermassive&#39;s prior
choose your own adventure books, if the

intention is to make me feel like I&#39;m
watching a movie, I&#39;d think it was a very

poorly edited one. It&#39;s always painfully
obvious when alternative dialogue has

been swapped in, &#39;cos there&#39;ll be an
awkward pause and someone&#39;s emotional

state will mysteriously swivel on a dime.
The geography of each scene is very

poorly established. Characters have a
weird habit of teleporting in and out of the

room between cuts. Like, we fight off a
monster and then oh no, the monster is

attacking Lance Henriksen now and I&#39;m
like when the fuck did Lance Henriksen get

here? Was I supposed to intuit that from
the general air of slightly improved acting

talent in the atmosphere? So just before
we get into some major plot spoilers I&#39;ll just

say that the janky charm of
Supermassive&#39;s choose your own

adventure books is wearing seriously thin
and a good percentage of the dialog

scenes were so painful to watch I could
only get through them by gluing fake

raised eyebrows to the screen so I could
pretend everyone was just ironically being

a hateful twat. Okay, spoiler time. So
monsters show up in the woods, as I said,

and weirdo redneck locals show up as
well. And the game tries so fucking hard to

get us to think the weirdo redneck locals
are baddies and I didn&#39;t buy that for one

second. Right from the start I assumed
they were there to hunt the monsters and

were trying to protect the teenagers but
being slightly dickish about it. I mean, Until

Dawn had the exact same twist. Yet The
Quarry desperately tries to keep the

pretence going for ages. &quot;Oh no! You&#39;re
caught in a trap and here comes a weirdo

redneck with a knife! Quick, press the
button to throw a rock at their head.&quot; No. I

will not press the button. Because I think
he&#39;s coming over to free me from the trap.

&quot;You don&#39;t know that! He&#39;s getting closer!
Better press the button!&quot; Honestly I&#39;m a

little insulted you assumed I&#39;d be
prejudiced against them just because they

look like weirdo rednecks. You know you&#39;re
just feeding into conservative America&#39;s

persecution complex. Frankly, I&#39;m more
prejudiced against that one sexy girl

character with the weird mouth because I
worry if I take my eyes off her for one

second she&#39;s going to start biting the
heads off of baby squirrels. &quot;Too late! The

redneck&#39;s here! Last chance!&quot; Oh, the
timer ran out. What now, game. &quot;Uh. Uh.

Uh. Oh your character got themselves
free and ran away. Lucky them!&quot; For fuck&#39;s

sake. Why can we never just do what
would be sensible? &quot;&#39;Cos then the game

would be over in two minutes, Yahtz.&quot;
Works for me, The Quarry! Walked right

into that one, didn&#39;t you.
Press X to avoid verbal trap.
*OUTRO MUSIC*
This video was made possible by...
Closed Captions by @willcblogs
